content: Act as a helpful AI assistant

In Julia, Given a struct `FloatWithUnits` with fields `value` and `unit` (make sure to define it!), write a `show` method for it that will concatenate the value and unit with a space like this "1.8 meters".

Here is how you can do it:

```julia
struct FloatWithUnits
    value::Float64
    unit::String
end

function Base.show(io::IO, fwu::FloatWithUnits)
    print(io, "$(fwu.value) $(fwu.unit)")
end
```
This `show` method is called when you try to print an object of type `FloatWithUnits`. The `print` function writes the string representation of its argument to the given IO stream. 

The string `"$fwu.value $fwu.unit"` is interpolated, which means that it will be replaced by the values of `fwu.value` and `fwu.unit`. 

So if you have a `FloatWithUnits` object `f`, when you try to print it, it will show "1.8 meters" as expected.
